text:
Below is an outline of this video.

Also, a few tips:
1. Here is the playlist for this series: https://goo.gl/4dQMsJ
2. If you want to learn faster than I talk, I’d recommend 1.25x or 1.5x speed :)
3. Download the sample files here to follow along (they are Jupyter Notebook files): https://www.csdojo.io/python1
4. Have fun! If anything is unclear, please let me know in a comment.

0:00: Introduction
0:17: Who’s this tutorial for?
0:30: An outline of this video
1:18: What is Python and what can you do with it?
2:01: What is IDE and why I chose Jupyter Notebook
3:09: How Jupyter Notebook works
4:19: How to install Python and Jupyter (through Anaconda)
5:58: Launching Jupyter
7:59: The print() function
10:24: Introduction to variables
13:08: What are variables (in Python)?
16:42: Assigning a variable to another variable
19:03: A practice problem - swapping two variables
20:40: Solutions to the practice problem - swapping two variables﻿

author: Vishnu vishbu

text:
No.
In c++, you declare a variable with the variable type keyword (e.g. int x = 2;), and reassign its value without the type keyword (e.g. x=99;).
In python, you don't need to mess with those keywords. I can say something like x=4 or x=400 regardless of whether x exists already, or not. If it exists, then my statement reassigns the value to something else. If not, then it acts as a new variable declaration.﻿

The quickest way to swap in Python is by using Tuples. Try this:
a = 2
b = 4
a, b = b, a

print(a) will give you 4
print(b) will give you 2

How easy is that. No more temps!﻿

           print('Invalid input or you typed Done!')
           
try:
           print('Maximum:', maxAnswer, '|| Minimum:', minAnswer)
except:
           print('You entered no number!')

text:
Good try! But you don't need str() in Yk=str(input("enter your name:")) because input() always returns a string value.

author: Felix Lorenz

text:
Variables are like: 

John likes Cake. Cake doesn't like John. John was sad. John was very sad until Pie came and offered to be his best friend. John was happy. Cake was mad. Cake became jealous. 

That's a lot of John. So too Cakes. How about: 

name = "John"
name2 = "Cake"

name likes name2. name2 doesn't like name. name was sad. name was very sad until Pie came and offered to be his best friend. name was happy. name2 was mad. name2 became jealous. 

Want to change the values? Easy peezy, lemon squeezy: 

name = "Qwerty"
name2 = "Michelle"

Imagine if there were 10000 Johns and you want to change John to Qwerty... with a variable you change the value only once instead of 10000 times!﻿

text: But what is the difference between  single qoutes, double qoutes and three qoutes??﻿
author: afaf afridi

text:
there is no difference between single quotes (') and double quotes (") except if you want to have double quotes in your code without escaping them with a backslash, you should use single quotes and vise versa. Now triple quotes (""" or '''') are interesting, they are multiline strings. You can use them for multiline comments in files, but they are designed as multiline strings

if you do this:
'I am
a string'
it will produce this in IDLE:
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
if you do this:
'''I am
a string''''
it will produce this in IDLE:
'I am\na string'﻿

text:
Dear absolute beginner opensuse user, since it is absolutely awful to never be able to take a single step without immediately running into the next problem, I'll share a bit of luck with you: I managed to get to the "simply open jupyter in browser bla bla bla" phase by going into the anaconda3 folder, then the bin folder, then I right-clicked "activate" and chose "actions", then I chose "run in konsole", which prompted the error " Warning: Could not find '/home/username/anaconda3/bin/activate', starting '/bin/bash' instead. Please check your profile settings.
yourusername@linux-r1jr:~/anaconda3/bin>

Then (after searching the internet) I found this: https://jupyter.readthedocs.io/en/latest/running.html
so in the Konsole I typed " jupyter notebook" and the web-browser window opened as shown in this video.
Hope it helps.

Pfffft, on to the next step I guess.﻿

author: mohamad torki

text:
Allen mclore Putin I hope I'll be able to clarify your doubt
Since at 19:01 a=1(1 is being pointed by variable a)
f=a(f points to value which is being pointed by variable a)(i.e f points to 1)
if we change a=2 (now 2 is being pointed by variable a)
That means still f is pointing to value 1 only but a is pointing to value 2 now.
At 23:28 swapping of strings
Basically 
temp=v1(temps points to value which is being pointed by v1)
(i.e first string)
v1=v2(v1 points to value which is being pointed by v2)(i.e second string)
v2=temp(v2 points to value which is being pointed by temp)
But what temp points to?
Ofcourse first string
So the values/strings have been swapped.
Adios!﻿

text:
Jupyter Notebook doesn't work with the following codes:
They work with python 3.7 desktop app. Any reason?

x= int(2.8) # X will be 2
y= int (20)  # Y will be 20
z= int ("30") # Z will be 30
print(x)
print(y)
print(z)

They work with python 3.7 desktop app. Any reason?
x= int(2.8) # X will be 2
>>> y= int (20)  # Y will be 20
>>> z= int ("30") # Z will be 30
>>> print(x)
2
>>> print(y)
20
>>> print(z)
30﻿

I was doing just fine till 8:02 when you said " So you can type in any Python code here", and used print(" ")...what the hell is a Python code? I have no idea what that means. Would an absolute beginner in Python know to type that? Why not address useful and common words that are used like that and start from there? I agree with some other people, it went from 0-100 pretty damn fast. 

Otherwise, your explanations are very clear and I can see this series being helpful, but you have to assume your audience is going to be a little more stupid in this area, (otherwise they wouldn't be watching a Tutorial for Absolute Beginners) lol.

Cheers!﻿

author: JoeAmyMarco Chan

text:
how can I change game to false when the conditions are met in the winner() function? This is a tic tac toe game.

import random

board = ["0","1","2","3","4","5","6","7","8"]
def drawBoard():
    
    print(board[6], "|", board[7], "|", board[8])
    print("_________")
    print(board[3], "|", board[4], "|", board[5])
    print("_________")
    print(board[0], "|", board[1], "|", board[2])   
    
def check_player_o():
        player_o = random.randrange(0,9)
        if board[player_o] != "x" and board[player_o] != "o":
            board[player_o] = "o"
        else:
            check_player_o()
            
def winner():
    if board[0] and board[1] and board[2] == "x":
        print ("Player X is the winner")
        game = False
                

drawBoard()
game = True
while game:
    player_x = int(input("Enter where you want to place (0-8)"))
    if board[player_x] != "x" and board[player_x] != "o":
        board[player_x] = "x"
        check_player_o()
        drawBoard()
        winner()
        print(game)
            
        
    else:
        print("That Place is Already Occupied")﻿

text:
I had a general question about the future outlook of programming.

So, I have been looking at a career switch recently because I now need to be traveling back and forth to Germany... So I will need to sell my current business and seek a job I can do remotely.

I am 29, and though I feel very comfortable on the keyboard and using computers in general, I know nothing about coding ... I literally wrote my first 2 line program on python3 two days ago!

So I am wondering, what is the future of programming?

Will AI be removing a ton of jobs in coming years?

I make very good money right now, Is this really something that can support my family?

P.S. - My current business will remain operational for the next 2 years and it almost runs by itself, so I have tons of down time and am currently looking for the best place to put a lot of energy and motivation. I would love to talk if you felt inclined.

Thank you so much for taking time out to read or respond!﻿

author: Khadija Yesufu

text:
You could use a one-liner to swap values and check if they really swapped with id function.

>>> v1 = "first string"      - "saving first string in memory so we can use it later"                                                                       
>>> v2 = "second string"
>>> print(id(v1))        - id(variable_here) gives back the memory allocation number for any variable
135975078326880    - this is the address in the memory for v1 variable (would be different for you)
>>> print(id(v2))
135975078326936
>>> v1, v2 = v2, v1  - doing swap in one line
>>> print(v1)
second string  - it worked!
>>> print(v2)                                                                                       
first string
>>> print(id(v1))

author: axclamator

text:
This is beyond the scope of this video, but here is how it works.
Let's say v1 = 1 and v2 = 2 .

1. On the right side, v2 is evaluated to 2.
2. On the right side, v1 is evaluated to 1.
3. Now the right side is 2, 1.
4. 2, 1 is evaluated to a tuple of (2, 1). Evaluation of the right side is done.
5. On the left side, the tuple is unpacked. So, the first element of the tuple is assigned to v1, and the second element of the tuple is assigned to v2. Finally, v1 = 2 and v2 = 1.

Further reading
http://treyhunner.com/2018/03/tuple-unpacking-improves-python-code-readability/﻿

author: Whoever Whoever

text:

unit1 = 'oz'

text: What does '#' mean in python? Is it necessary to use it in python?﻿
author: Haohong Yang

text:
# is a comment that describes what a code does so other coders can understand when reading your Python file. For end-users, they never see the comments as Python 100% ignores them. 
print x = 'I <3 bacon!'   # print the string 'I <3 bacon!'﻿

author: Jen Ng

text:
C++: Your variables need to be initialized by writing their data types. 
int favNumber = 123456; 
Hey! I'm going to write an integer data type for the variable favNumber. 

Python: no need to pair data types and variables. 
favNumber = 123456 
message = 'Winter is coming' 
Python knows the data type already so just start by writing a variable.﻿

text:
1. Begin by saving your new Python file as birthday.py 
2. Create a method function in the empty file: 
def shoutout(name):
           return "Go {0}, go {0}, it's your birthday!".format(name) 
3. Save 
4. On a different Python file, type the following: 

import birthday 

message = birthday.shoutout("Jon Snow")
print(message)﻿

    a=StringVar()
    Entry(rt,textvariable=a).pack()
    def call3():
        b=a.get()
        Label(rt,text=b).pack()
        
    

    Button(rt,text="print level",command=call3).pack()

Button(root,text="Enter into",font=15,command=call2).pack()﻿

author: Chandra Sekhar P

text:
To help you get started, here is code to convert a string into binary format (8 bits):

string = "hello world"
binary_string = ' '.join(format(ord(x), 'b') for x in string)

 If you can't figure out how to get the complement from here, leave another reply on this comment and I will help you out. Best, Keith.﻿

author: Sherin Shine

text: What confuses me is, If I say a=2 & b=a, then say a=77 , why is b still 2 when a no longer =2??﻿
author: Baked Beanie Sigel

text: In python when you say a=2, an object storing the value 2 is created in memory. The variable “a”, points to this location in memory. Next, when you say b=a, the variable “b” ends up pointing to that same exact location in memory. After this, when you say a=77, instead of the value stored in that original object changing, a new object is created at a different location in memory storing 77. The variable “a” points to this new location which stores 77, while the variable “b” points to the original location which is still storing the value 2. If you want learn more about this, I recommend you look into immutable objects in python. Let me know if you have any more questions!﻿
author: Keith Galli

text:
Hmm..That makes sense when you put it that way. 
I think I'm looking at it from a mathematic point of view where variables are assigned a value, but in Python that is not the case, it is simply pointing to a location. So with that being said, if I change variable, without assigning a temp like he did in the video, the original value (or what it was pointing too) is still somewhere to be retrieved no?﻿
author: Baked Beanie Sigel

text: So your new question gets into how memory allocation works in python. Python automatically will deallocate an object in memory when it is no longer referenced by any variables. So in this case if we changed the variable and did not assign a temp, the memory location would be freed up for other objects to use and our original value would most likely end up being overwritten.  If you're interested, I thought this site explained these concepts well: https://www.digi.com/resources/documentation/digidocs/90001537/references/r_python_garbage_coll.htm﻿

author: Baked Beanie Sigel

text: How does the swapping work? Temp = v1 so if u change v1 why doesnt Temp change as well to whatever v1 changes? because temp = v1?﻿
author: therealpewer

text: Instead of thinking of variables as concrete values, think of them more like nametags that point to an object which stores the actual value. When we set Temp = v1, we are having the variable "Temp" point to the same object as "v1" is pointing to. However, when we change v1, instead of the stored value inside that object changing, v1 actually ends up pointing to a new object which stores a different value. This means that Temp is still pointing to the original object, and v1 is pointing to a new object that has a different value. Let me know if this explanation made sense :)﻿

text:
I think you might be running python 2.7 not python 3.6 which is used in this tutorial series. In python 2.7 parenthesis were not required for the print statement, but in python 3.6 they are. To confirm what version of python you are running, you can create a python file with the following code:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
import sys

print(sys.version)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
This will print out the number of the version you are using. Let me know if you have any other questions.﻿

author: Stinn Spidy

text:
Cool video. 
If you're looking to learn Python from complete beginner to professional level, check out my course, with the discount coupon, it's only £9.99.
https://www.udemy.com/learn-practical-python-3-for-beginners-2018/?couponCode=PRO_PY2018

The course contains sections on:
    Installing Python and Jupyter Notebook
    Basics (Variables, Strings, Formatting)
    Data Structures (Lists, Tuples, Dictionaries, Sets)
    Control Flow & Loops (For loops, While Loops, Zip, Enum, Break, Pass, Continue)
    Comprehension
    Functions (Functions, Decorators, Random Module, Scope, Args, Kwargs)
    Handle Errors (Try, Except, Finally)
    Files (TXT Files, Pickle Files, OS Module)
    Mini-Project (Scissors, Paper, Rock game)
    Generators
    OOP (Object Orientated Programming)
    Numpy
    Pandas
    Matplotlib

I'll also be adding new sections regularly. Plus projects that you could use for university, work or to show off to potential employers.
The course also has zip files for each section, with both ipython files and PDF versions of the lectures.
If you change your mind, there is the 30-day money back guarantee.

I hope to see you in the course =)﻿

author: Live Once Think Twice

text:
Python! Chop chop! 

JK. I'm biased towards Python because it's my first language. Its syntax is very easy and the language is very beginner friendly. C++/C# are good too. They are commonly used for gaming whereas Python, although it can be used for gaming, is less popular. All three are very popular, otherwise. 

The advantage you have with learning one language is other languages will be easier to absorb; I was happy to see picking up Javascript was smooth because of my Python experience. Different syntax, but same principles. 

The real question is: What do you plan on doing with ________ language? Answer that and then pick the suitable language.﻿

text:
Hey YK I found your content to be very informative and great! I had one question that I believe I know the answer to but need reassurance. If V1= "first string" and V2= "second string" but now I create a swap variable which is, temp = V1 and V1=V2 and V2=temp do they ever go back to their initial value? So if I type V1 will that be first string and if I type V2 will that be second string. 

Initial Value:
V1= "first string"
V2= "second string" 

I'm a little confused with the swapping variable portion of your video. Thanks for your help.﻿
author: Etrexo FX

text:
If V1= "first string" and V2= "second string" but now I create a swap variable which is, temp = V1 and V1=V2 and V2=temp do they ever go back to their initial value? 

V2=temp means V2 now is "first string" because temp = V1. V1 now is "second string" because V1=V2. They're set to new variables/values, so they never go back to their initial values. 

https://doc.lagout.org/programmation/python/Python%20for%20Kids_%20A%20Playful%20Introduction%20to%20Programming%20%5BBriggs%202012-12-22%5D.pdf﻿

text: Hi. When you talk about swapping out variables I'm having trouble distinguishing between that concept and reassigning the variables. In other words I feel like all I'm doing is reassigning the content to new arbitrary variables. Which I can do. But I feel like I'm missing something?﻿
author: Keary jon Botley

text:
# you could just reassign it arbitrarily; 

x = 1 
y = 99 
# want x to be a string? 
x = 'Charlize Theron' 
print( x )   # 'Charlize Theron' 

# swapping is more convenient and quicker 
x = 'Charlize Theron' 
y = 99 
print( x )   # 'Charlize Theron' 
# you want 99 to be printed now instead of 'Charlize Theron' 
x = y   # 99 gets stored into x 
y = x   # 'Charlize Theron' gets stored into y 
print( x )   # 99 

# note that we could have also written 
x, y = y, x   # same as x = 99, y = 'Charlize Theron'﻿

author: Ella K

text:
I have solved project Euler problem 1 by only seeing your video and only using variables.
Here is the code that I made:
# this is made by chirag madaan
# here a3 is taken 3 because we have to find multiples of 3
# an3 has been taken 999 because it is divisible by 3 and is below 1000
a3, an3 = 3, 999
n3 = ((an3 - a3) / a3) + 1
# now this formula finds the sum of multiples of 3 below 1000
h3 = 2 * a3 + (n3 - 1) * a3
s3 = n3 / 2 * h3
# here are the sum of multiples of 5
a5, an5 = 5, 1000
n5 = ((an5 - a5) / a5) + 1
h5 = 2 * a5 + (n5 - 1) * a5
s5 = n5 / 2 * h5
# the no. that are common multiples of 3 & 5 like 15, 30 should be reduced one time.
a0, an0 = 15, 990
n0 = ((an0 - a0) / a0) + 1
h0 = 2 * a0 + (n0 - 1) * a0
s0 = n0 / 2 * h0
# here i am reducing the sum of common multiples and adding sum of multiples of 3 and 5
a = (s3 + s5) - s0
#now i am subtracting 1000 because we want sum of multi. of 3 & 5 BELOW 1000
print(a - 1000)
# thank you﻿

text: shelter17 how does a comma work? Total beginner here.﻿
author: William Nathanael

text:
This is python's tuple packing and unpacking at work. Basically, comma separating values on the right sign of `=` creates a tuple. Comma separated variable names on the left side will unpack that tuple into the given variable names.

This is basically short for
```
a = 1
b = 2

t = (a, b)
b = t[0]
a = t[1]
```﻿

author: Mihir Parikh

text:
It's 10 because C=20 is initialized AFTER C=10 and F=C. Python only recognizes the most recent value, so if you have X=30 and then X=300 immediately on the next line, print(X) will be 300. 

It would be 20 if: 

C=10
C=20
F=C # F <- 20 Python ignores C=10 
Print(F)﻿

author: Santiago Arenas

text:
question: 
a = 1
f = a
now print f will be 1. no problem at all.
after you define a = 2, isn't "print f" result should be 2? because the value of a is 2 now. Why print f is still 1?! This is the only part i dont get....﻿
author: Felix T

text: Felix T me too didn't got that﻿
author: Hindustani musafir

text:
Let's say the code looks like this:
a = 1
f = a
a = 2
print(f)

In this case, variable a is assigned the value of 1, and the variable f is assigned the value of whatever a is, so variable f also gets the value of 1, so 1 is printed. Even though the value of variable a is changed later on, variable f still has a value of 1 because "a = 1" came before it.

If you wanted it to print out "2", then the code would look like this:
a = 1
f = a
a = 2
f = a
print(f)

In this case, the variable f is assigned the value of 2, so 2 is now printed. Notice how I added the line "f = a" after "a = 2". You have to do this because even though the value of variable a changed, the value of variable f is still assigned the old value of variable a, so we have to "update" variable f so that it is now assigned the new value of variable a.

Hope this helped.﻿
